questions.text: Remote after loading is used in:-
questions.solution:
In afterloading procedures, an unloaded applicator is inserted first and the radioactive sources are introduced later. Afterloading has been utilized in many recently described uterine applicators, but the radiation exposure of physicians, nurses, and visitors during the treatment remains a serious problem.In principle, complete elimination of all unnecessary radiation exposure is possible by 'remote after-loading,' which has been used for small teleradium bombs for more than twenty-five years and is widely applied in industrial radiography with gamma-ray sources.

KEY TAKEAWAY- In remote after loading radiation exposure to the surrounding tissue is reduced.

Reference: Remote Afterloading with Intracavitary Applicators Ulrich K. Henschke, Basil S. Hilaris, and G.D. Mahan Radiology 1964 83:2, 344-345

questions.text: Which sign is seen on USG when the femoral vein meets the GSV and femoral artery at the saphenofemoral junction?
questions.solution:
Duplex ultrasonography is probably the most frequently used investigation to evaluate the venous system for the management of chronic venous disease (CVD) of the lower limbs. The 'Mickey Mouse' sign is used to identify the GSV and the common femoral vein, both lying medial to the common femoral artery.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Mickey mouse sign

On usg thigh seen in SFJ.

on usg liver - Portal Triad

On antenatal scan - Anencephaly

Mri Brain -Progressive supranuclear palsy

On bone scan - Paget's disease

Reference: Coleridge-Smith P, Labropoulos N, Partsch H, Myers K, Nicolaides A, Cavezzi A. Duplex ultrasound investigation of the veins in chronic venous disease of the lower limbs--UIP consensus document. Part I. Basic principles. Eur J Vasc Endovasc Surg. 2006 Jan;31(1):83-92. doi: 10.1016/j.ejvs.2005.07.019. Epub 2005 Oct 14. PMID: 16226898.

questions.text: A 60 year old female with chronic backache. Radiograph of the lumbar spine was performed. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Osteoporosis is a metabolic bone disease characterized by decreased bone mass and skeletal fragility.

The World Health Organization (WHO) operationally defines osteoporosis as a bone mineral density T-score less than -2.5 SD (more than 2.5 standard deviations under the young-adult mean), which is measured by dual-energy x-ray absorptiometry (DEXA), in postmenopausal women and men at least 50 years old.

Vertebral osteoporosis manifests as

  • Penciling of vertebrae
  • Loss of cortical bone and trabecular bone (ghost vertebra)
  • Compression fractures and vertebra plana (Genant classification of vertebral fractures)
  • Prominent vertical (primary) trabeculae with thinning of horizontal/secondary trabeculae in vertebral bodies

KEY TAKEAWAY- fish mouth vertebrae seen in osteoporosis.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGls Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2885

questions.text: A 20 year old man with hypertension has the following chest X-ray finding with a prominent aortic knuckle. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of aorta refers to a narrowing of the distal aortic arch and/or proximal descending aorta due to a discrete membrane or narrowing of the aortic isthmus. In an uncomplicated isolated coarctation, the heart size is usually normal. There may be left ventricular configuration. The classical feature of bilateral notching of the posterior and inferior margins of the 4th-8th ribs is usually not seen in the first decade of life. The coarct segment is usually located in the juxtaductal region Rib notching is caused by the hypertrophied intercostal arteries that run along the posterior and inferior margins of the ribs. Abnormal appearance of the aorta is seen in most patients. The ascending aorta is slightly dilated. Figure-of-3 appearance of the descending aorta is seen.


Reverse 3 sign seen on Barium swallow.


Rib notching is caused by the hypertrophied intercostal arteries that run along the posterior and inferior margins of the ribs.

Key TAKEAWAY- on Barium swallow reverse 3 sign seen

Rosler's sign - Inferior Rib notching ( seen due to collateral circulation btw anterior and posterior intercoastal artery). It is seen in child with COA >10 year.

It is seen from [3rd - 10th ]Ribs not in first 2 Rib.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2638

questions.text: Cystic lesion in suprasellar region with calcification?
questions.solution:
The given lesion is craniopharyngioma. Craniopharyngioma (CP) is a benign, often partly cystic sellar/suprasellar mass that probably arises from epithelial remnants of Rathke's pouch.CPs are primarily suprasellar tumors. CPs follow a 'rule of ninety,' i.e., 90% are mixed cystic/solid, 90% are calcified, and 90%enhanced.

In meningioma dural tail sign is seen on CT scan.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2 page 798

questions.text: A child presented with some skeletal abnormality and the radiograph was obtained and an angle is being measured. What is the name of the angle measured?
questions.solution:
Scoliosis is defined as a lateral spinal curvature with a Cobb angle of 10° or more. This abnormal curvature may be the result of an underlying congenital or developmental osseous or neurologic abnormality, but in most cases the cause is unknown. The Cobb angle of a scoliotic curve is the angle formed by the intersection of two lines, one parallel to the endplate of the superior end vertebra and the other parallel to the endplate of the inferior end vertebra. The angle may be plotted manually or digitally.


Diagram demonstrating measurement of cobb's angle.

Reference: Scoliosis Imaging: What Radiologists Should Know

questions.text: A 60 yr old Female with intermittent bleeding per vagina, endometrial collection and with thickening and anterior bulging of the fundal area on Ultrasound showing a Feeding Vessel sign. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
focal thickening of endometrium with a feeding vessel sign is suggestive of endometrial polyp.

Endometrial cancer is a diffuse thickening.


Image showing endometrial polyp with feeding vessel sign on color doppler.

questions.text: An infertile woman undergoing treatment for infertility with IVF was given inj. HMG. She presented with abdominal distension and vomiting. The USG is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ovarian hyperstimulation syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of ovulation induction or ovarian stimulation.

It occurs during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle or in early pregnancy and mostly follows administration of endogenous or exogenous LH or hCG. It occurs after hCG administration to patients with a large number of immature follicles and high serum estradiol levels and is more likely to occur in those with a polycystic ovarian morphology.

It is characterized by third-space fluid accumulation and electrolyte abnormalities.

On imaging, symmetric enlargement of bilateral ovaries is seen which contain multiple cystic areas of varying sizes which represent enlarged follicles or corpus luteal cysts in the presence of ascites. The "spoke wheel" appearance has been described with peripherally located follicles surrounding a central core of ovarian stroma. The cysts are usually anechoic but may contain hemorrhage.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Increased hcg due to exogenous cause like infertility treatment - OHSS

Increased hcg due to endogenous causes like molar pregnancy, multigestation - Theca lutein cyst.


Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 362

questions.text: 45 year old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity. There is no history of trauma.
questions.solution:
subarachnoid spaces (SASs) are CSF-filled cavities that lie between the arachnoid and the pia. Hemorrhage into the SAS is known as subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).Sometimes, blood in the SAS is refluxed into the cerebral ventricles, producing secondary intraventricular hemorrhage. The typical location of SAH (basal cisterns and sylvian and inferior interhemispheric fissures). The gross appearance of a SAH is typically characterized by blood-filled basal cisterns. Rupture of an aneurysm typically leads to SAH.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

Mc cause of subarachnoid Hemorrhage is Trauma.

Mc cause of spontaneous subarachnoid Hemorrhage is rupture of berry aneurysm.

IOC for SAH- NCCT.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2, pg 123.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of the patient with the following chest X-ray?
questions.solution:
TOF is the most common cyanotic heart disease. Chest xray shows boot shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy, apex is turned upward.

Tetralogy of fallot consists of -

  • pulmonary stenosis,
  • ventricular septal defect
  • overriding of aorta
  • right ventricle hypertrophy.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

TOF - Boot shaped heart

TAPVC- figure of 8 appearance.

TGA - egg on string appearance

Ebstein's anomaly - Box shaped heart.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 2588

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis of following barium swallow images?
questions.solution:
In barium contrast studies, esophageal adenocarcinoma presents with a variety of morphologic abnormalities. They may appear as annular apple-core lesion with overhanging margins, irregular narrowed segment, smooth tapering stricture, bulky endophytic mass, large ulceration, varicoid infiltrate, or diffuse nodularity.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • shouldering and irregular narrowing seen in ca esophagus.
  • In Achalasia cardia bird beak appearance seen

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1684

questions.text: A 7 week pregnant lady accidently exposed to chest X ray in the hospital. What is to be done?
questions.solution:
• A single chest X-ray exposes the fetus to a very low dose of radiation (0.002 to 0.01 rad or 0.02 to 0.1 mGy), which is far below the teratogenic threshold.
  • The critical threshold for fetal damage is 5-10 rad (50-100 mGy). Below this level, there is no significant risk of congenital malformations, miscarriage, or intellectual disability.
  • Radiation effects on the fetus depend on gestational age and dose:
    • 0-2 weeks: "All or none" effect (either miscarriage or no effect).
    • 2-8 weeks: Organogenesis phase, but low-dose radiation does not cause major anomalies.
    • 8-15 weeks: Higher risk of cognitive impairment with high radiation exposure (>10 rad).
    • After 15 weeks: Much lower risk unless exposure is very high.
  • Since the fetal dose is negligible, the pregnancy should be continued.

Other options:

(A) Immediate termination of pregnancy

  • Termination is not justified because the radiation dose from a chest X-ray is far below the harmful threshold.
  • The fetus is in the early embryonic stage (7 weeks), where low-dose radiation does not cause severe congenital anomalies.
  • Medical guidelines (like those from the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists - ACOG) do not recommend termination for such low exposures.

(B) Do pre-invasive test (e.g., amniocentesis or CVS)

  • Pre-invasive tests (e.g., chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis) are done if there is a high risk of genetic abnormalities, which is not the case here.
  • Radiation does not cause chromosomal disorders like Down syndrome; it mainly increases the risk of malformations and growth restriction at high doses.
  • Invasive tests carry a risk of miscarriage, so they should not be done unless strongly indicated.

(C) Do chromosomal testing

  • Radiation does not cause chromosomal abnormalities like trisomy 21, 18, or 13.
  • Chromosomal testing (like karyotyping or NIPT) is done when there is a family history or abnormal screening results, not for radiation exposure.
  • A single X-ray does not increase the risk of genetic mutations significantly.

Reference: Christensen's physics of diagnostic radiology page 379

questions.text: Patient presenting with blood in stools and mass palpable on examination.A barium study was performed and shown below. What could be the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Intussusception occurs when one segment of the bowel is pulled into itself or a neighboring loop of the bowel by peristalsis. The classic triad of intermittent abdominal pain, vomiting, and right upper quadrant mass, plus occult or gross blood on rectal examination. A contrast enema remains the gold standard, demonstrating the intussusception as an occluding mass prolapsing into the lumen, giving the "coiled spring" appearance (barium in the lumen of the intussusceptum and in the intraluminal space).

On usg - Target /Doughnut sign is seen.


KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • claw sign/pincer clasp/coiled spring appearance is seen on Barium enema.
  • Target /Doughnut sign is seen on usg.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1144

questions.text: Find below the contrast study and identify the investigation and possible diagnosis-
questions.solution:
The given image shows a micturating cystourethrogram as evidenced by presence of contrast in the bladder. It shows narrowing in the penile urethra suggestive of stricture.


KEY TAKEAWAY-

RGU - IOC for urethral stricture, urethral trauma, anterior urethra

MCU- IOC for VUR, evaluating posterior urethral valves.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 211

questions.text: An HSG was performed in patient with infertility. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Tubal dilatation results from an accumulation of secretions when the tube is occluded at its distal end, fimbrial/ampullary end, or both ends, with dilatation of the proximal portion of the tube. Hydrosalpinx is used as a generic term for a dilated tube. A hysterosalpingogram will show a dilated fallopian tube, filling with contrast and with absence of free spillage. It can be tubular or retort-shaped.

KEY TAKEAWAY- Normal hsg will show free spillage of contrast.

In TB bilateral hydrosalpinx will be seen.

Best time for hsg - 6th-10th day of menstrual cycle.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 268

questions.text: A patient with the neck swelling and regurgitation and frequent aspiration. There is gurgling sound when pressed in the neck region. A barium swallow was performed. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Zenker's diverticulum is a false diverticula which involves herniation of the mucosa and submucosa through the muscular layer of esophagus.

It is a pouch that develops as an area of anatomic weakness in the posterior hypopharyngeal wall between the horizontal and oblique fibers of the cricopharyngeus muscle. It is seen on the lateral view as a bulge or true sac extending posteriorly from the posterior hypopharyngeal wall just above the cricopharyngeal impression.impression. On the frontal view a Zenker's diverticulum is seen as a barium-filled sac below the arcuate lines of the pyriform sinuses. This area is known as the triangle of Killian or Killian dehiscence.

Given image shows a diverticulum arising from the lateral pharyngeal wall. This is suggestive of pharyngeal pouch.

KEY TAKEAWAY- left lateral diverticulum- killian- Jamieson diverticulum

Posterior diverticulum- Zenker's diverticulum.

On barium swallow crescentic narrowing of esophagus with calcification- esophageal leiomyomas

Corkscrew appearance on Barium swallow- Diffuse esophageal spasm

Serpiginous worm-like filling defect - esophageal varices

Mucosal ring at lower part of esophagus- schatzki ring.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1665

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with fever and biphasic stridor. There is history of prior URI. There is no dysphagia. What is the diagnosis on the basis of radiograph given below?
questions.solution:
Croup, also known as acute laryngotracheobronchitis, is due to viral infection of the upper airway by parainfluenza virus or respiratory syncytial virus.

Affected children present with "croupy" (barky) cough and inspiratory stridor.

On frontal radiographs, there is loss of the normal shoulders (lateral convexities) of the subglottic trachea due to subglottic edema. The subglottic trachea becomes elongated, extending below the level of the pyriform sinuses. The appearance is referred to as a "church steeple" or "inverted V" appearance. Lateral radiographs may reveal similar narrowing of the subglottic trachea with loss of its wall definition.

KEY TAKEAWAY-

  • Steeple sign seen in acute laryngotracheobronchitis
  • Thumb sign seen in acute Epiglottitis.

Thumb sign

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2488.

questions.text: Pulmonary plethora is seen in:
questions.solution:
• Pulmonary plethora refers to increased pulmonary blood flow, seen on chest X-ray as prominent pulmonary vessels.
  • It occurs in left-to-right shunts or obstructed venous return, leading to increased pulmonary circulation and congestion.
  • TAPVC (Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection) is a congenital heart defect where pulmonary veins do not connect to the left atrium, instead draining into systemic veins or the right atrium.
  • This results in excessive pulmonary blood flow, causing pulmonary plethora on X-ray.

Chest X-ray findings in TAPVC:

  • Prominent pulmonary arteries
  • Increased vascular markings (plethora)
  • "Snowman sign" (in supracardiac TAPVC)

Thus, TAPVC is the correct answer because it causes pulmonary plethora due to excessive pulmonary venous return.

Other options:

(A) TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot)

  • TOF consists of four defects:
    1. Pulmonary stenosis (causing decreased pulmonary blood flow)
    2. Right ventricular hypertrophy
    3. Overriding aorta
    4. Ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Pulmonary stenosis reduces pulmonary blood flow, leading to pulmonary oligemia (reduced lung markings on X-ray), not plethora.
  • X-ray in TOF: "Boot-shaped heart" with decreased lung markings.
  • Incorrect because TOF causes pulmonary oligemia, not plethora.

(C) Coarctation of Aorta

  • Coarctation of the aorta is a narrowing of the aortic arch, leading to:
    • Increased upper body blood flow (hypertension in arms)
    • Decreased lower body blood flow (weak femoral pulses)
    • Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH) due to increased afterload
  • Pulmonary blood flow is not significantly increased, so no pulmonary plethora is seen.
  • X-ray in Coarctation: Rib notching, figure-3 sign (due to collateral circulation).
  • Incorrect because coarctation does not cause pulmonary plethora.

(D) Tricuspid Atresia

  • In tricuspid atresia, the tricuspid valve is absent, leading to:
    • Hypoplastic right ventricle
    • Reduced pulmonary blood flow (causing oligemia)
    • Cyanosis
  • Pulmonary oligemia (decreased lung markings on X-ray) occurs because blood cannot easily reach the lungs.
  • X-ray in Tricuspid Atresia: Small right heart border, decreased pulmonary markings.
  • Incorrect because tricuspid atresia causes pulmonary oligemia, not plethora.

questions.text: 35 year old man presenting with recurrent episodes of fever with chills and fatigue. An MRCP image is given. Diagnosis
questions.solution:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC) is an idiopathic, chronic, fibrosing inflammatory disorder affecting the biliary radicles leading to obstruction of bile ducts, cholestasis, progressing to biliary cirrhosis. It has a strong association with ulcerative colitis. It is thought to be an autoimmune process due to its association with other autoimmune disorders including mediastinal fibrosis, Sjögren syndrome, and retroperitoneal fibrosis.
ERCP, which has been the gold standard for diagnosis of PSC, is associated with risk of cholangitis following bile stasis and biliary injury because of presence of sacculations with increased stiffness of the biliary system. MRCP has been shown equivalent to ERCP for detecting and localizing the levels of obstruction in the biliary system, and can be helpful in establishing the diagnosis as well as help in planning for an intervention.

Diagnostic criteria include:

  • Typical cholangiographic abnormalities: Multifocal, intrahepatic strictures involving the biliary ducts alternating with normal-sized ducts producing a beaded appearance.
  • Clinical, biochemical, and liver histology findings: Patients present with progressive fatigue, pruritus, or jaundice. Elevated serum bilirubin and ALP is seen in most of the patients, with ALP rise at least three times the normal range. Liver biopsy shows inflammatory fibrosis (nonspecific) involving the portal tracts with a scarcity of bile ducts. Therefore, the histology is considered for confirmation only in case there is a suspicion of PSC.
  • Excluding the secondary causes of sclerosing cholangitis

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 1981

questions.text: A female patient presents with shortness of breath and B/L basal fields. A photograph of the hand of the patient is shown below. What is the next step in the case?
questions.solution:
A patient with shortness of breath , systemic sclerosis with reticular opacities in b/l basal fields suggestive of ILD( Interstitial lung disease). IOC for ILD is HRCT.

For Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGl's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 2690

Reference image: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nail_clubbing

questions.text: Occipito mental view with an open mouth is best described by which x ray ?
questions.solution:
caldwell view (occipito- frontal view)- for frontal sinus /superior orbital fissure

Water's view(occipito-Mental view)- Maxillary sinus

Rhese view (Lateral oblique)- ethmoid sinus/optic canal.

Pierre's View (occipito mental with open mouth)- sphenoid and maxillary sinus.

Base skull view(submentovertical view) - sphenoid sinus.

Towne's View- AP view of skull with 30 degree angulation.

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page 3308

choices.text: Rapidly dividing cells are resistant to radiation
GI mucosa is one of the most radioresistant tissues in the GIT
The dose of the radiation is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source
Small vessels are resistant to radiation

questions.text: Which of the following is the true statement in relation to radiation sensitivity of the tissues?
questions.solution:
The radiation at a point is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the source. This is known as inverse square law and is used in reducing the patient dose.

The normal cell and cancer cells(rapidly dividing cells) are not equally sensitive .Cancer cells are more radiosensitive.

GI mucosa is more sensitive to radiation.

Small blood vessels are not resistant to the effect of radiation

Reference: Cristensen's physics of diagnostic radiology, page 115, 375

questions.text: Which is not seen in heart failure?
questions.solution:
kerley B lines are thin horizontal lines parallel to each other at the base of lungs typically associated with interstitial pulmonary edema.

Kerley A lines - are perihilar lines.

Oligemia is not seen; instead of it plethora is seen in upper lobes.

KEY TAKEAWAY-


Reference- Pulmonary oedema | Radiology Reference Article | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: A middle-aged man presents with abdominal pain following a heavy meal and alcohol consumption. X-ray examination reveals widening of the mediastinum with pneumomediastinum. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alcoholic pt with pain abdomen with pneumomediastinum Suggestive of esophageal rupture I.e Boerhaave syndrome.

  1. Perforated Peptic Ulcer: While this can also present with abdominal pain, it typically doesn't cause pneumomediastinum rather causes pneumoperitoneum.
  2. Foreign Body in Esophagus: This might cause difficulty swallowing but not necessarily pneumomediastinum.
  3. Rupture of Emphysematous Bulla: This is less likely in this scenario as it usually presents with respiratory symptoms.

Reference - Boerhaave syndrome | Radiology Case | Radiopaedia.org

questions.text: Personal dose monitoring is done by?
questions.solution:
Persons who are exposed to radiation need to be monitored during the course of their work. The dosimeters should be properly worn, should receive proper care and be returned on time. Various dosimeters include pocket dosimeter, the film badge or thermoluminescent dosimeter.

TLD.

The aim of personal monitoring is:

  • To monitor and control individual doses.
  • To be able to detect overexposures and suggest corrective measures.
  • To maintain a record of the cumulative dose records.

Types of Dosimeter

  • Immediate read
  • Pocket Ionization Chambers
  • Ionization detectors with dose accumulation function
  • Delayed read/Personnel monitors
  • Film Badges
  • TLD
  • Optically Stimulated Light-emitting Dosimeters

KEY TAKEAWAY- TLD made up of lithium fluoride / caso4 dysprosium.

It measures radiation exposure in occupational workers

It should be worn at chest level under a lead apron.

Usually read every 3 months .

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PGI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 845
